From 1997 to 1998, _[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's
Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone "Harry Potter and the
Philosopher's Stone")_ won almost all the UK awards judged by children, but
none of the children's book awards judged by adults,[167] and Sandra Beckett
suggested the reason was [intellectual snobbery](/wiki/Intellectual_snobbery
"Intellectual snobbery") towards books that were popular among children.[168]
In 1999, the winner of the [Whitbread Book of the Year
award](/wiki/Whitbread_Book_Award "Whitbread Book Award") children's division
was entered for the first time on the shortlist for the main award, and one
judge threatened to resign if _[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of
Azkaban](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban "Harry Potter and the
Prisoner of Azkaban")_ was declared the overall winner; it finished second,
very close behind the winner of the poetry prize, [Seamus
Heaney](/wiki/Seamus_Heaney "Seamus Heaney")'s translation of the [Anglo-
Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon "Anglo-Saxon") [epic](/wiki/Epic_poetry "Epic
poetry") _[Beowulf](/wiki/Beowulf "Beowulf")_.[168]

In 2000, shortly before the publication of _[Harry Potter and the Goblet of
Fire](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire "Harry Potter and the Goblet
of Fire")_ , the previous three _Harry Potter_ books topped _The New York
Times_ fiction best-seller list and a third of the entries were children's
books. The newspaper created a new children's section covering children's
books, including both fiction and non-fiction, and initially counting only
hardback sales. The move was supported by publishers and booksellers.[107] In
2004, _The New York Times_ further split the children's list, which was still
dominated by _Harry Potter_ books into sections for series and individual
books, and removed the _Harry Potter_ books from the section for individual
books.[169] The split in 2000 attracted condemnation, praise and some comments
that presented both benefits and disadvantages of the move.[170] _Time_
suggested that, on the same principle, Billboard should have created a
separate "[mop-tops](/wiki/Mop-top "Mop-top")" list in 1964 when the
[Beatles](/wiki/Beatles "Beatles") held the top five places in its list, and
[Nielsen](/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research "Nielsen Media Research") should have
created a separate game-show list when _[Who Wants to Be a
Millionaire?](/wiki/Who_Wants_to_Be_a_Millionaire%3F "Who Wants to Be a
Millionaire?")_ dominated the [ratings](/wiki/Nielsen_ratings "Nielsen
ratings").[171]

## Adaptations

### Films

Main article: [Harry Potter (film series)](/wiki/Harry_Potter_\(film_series\)
"Harry Potter \(film series\)")

[![The red locomotive train used as the "Hogwarts Express" in the film series.
In the front it has the numbers "5912" inscripted on
it](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/GWR_%27Hall%27_5972_%27Olton_Hall%27_at_Doncaster_Works.JPG/220px-
GWR_%27Hall%27_5972_%27Olton_Hall%27_at_Doncaster_Works.JPG)](/wiki/File:GWR_%27Hall%27_5972_%27Olton_Hall%27_at_Doncaster_Works.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:GWR_%27Hall%27_5972_%27Olton_Hall%27_at_Doncaster_Works.JPG
"Enlarge")

The locomotive that features as the "Hogwarts Express" in the film series.

In 1998, Rowling sold the film rights of the first four _Harry Potter_ books
to [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") for a reported £1 million
($1,982,900).[172][173] Rowling demanded the principal cast be kept strictly
British, nonetheless allowing for the inclusion of Irish actors such as the
late [Richard Harris](/wiki/Richard_Harris_\(actor\) "Richard Harris
\(actor\)") as Dumbledore, and for casting of French and Eastern European
actors in _[Harry Potter and the Goblet of
Fire](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire "Harry Potter and the Goblet
of Fire")_ where characters from the book are specified as such.[174] After
many directors including [Steven Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven
Spielberg"), [Terry Gilliam](/wiki/Terry_Gilliam#Gilliam_and_Harry_Potter
"Terry Gilliam"), [Jonathan Demme](/wiki/Jonathan_Demme "Jonathan Demme"), and
[Alan Parker](/wiki/Alan_Parker "Alan Parker") were considered, [Chris
Columbus](/wiki/Chris_Columbus_\(filmmaker\) "Chris Columbus \(filmmaker\)")
was appointed on 28 March 2000 as the director for _[Harry Potter and the
Philosopher's Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone_\(film\)
"Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone \(film\)")_ (titled "_Harry Potter
and the Sorcerer 's Stone_" in the United States), with Warner Bros. citing
his work on other family films such as _[Home Alone](/wiki/Home_Alone "Home
Alone")_ and _[Mrs. Doubtfire](/wiki/Mrs._Doubtfire "Mrs. Doubtfire")_ and
proven experience with directing children as influences for their
decision.[175]

After [extensive casting](/wiki/List_of_Harry_Potter_films_cast_members "List
of Harry Potter films cast members"), filming began in October 2000 at
[Leavesden Film Studios](/wiki/Leavesden_Film_Studios "Leavesden Film
Studios") and in London itself, with production ending in July 2001.[176][177]
_Philosopher 's Stone_ was released on 14 November 2001. Just three days after
the film's release, production for _[Harry Potter and the Chamber of
Secrets](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets_\(film\) "Harry Potter
and the Chamber of Secrets \(film\)")_ , also directed by Columbus, began.
Filming was completed in summer 2002, with the film being released on 15
November 2002.[178] [Daniel Radcliffe](/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe "Daniel
Radcliffe") portrayed [Harry Potter](/wiki/Harry_Potter_\(character\) "Harry
Potter \(character\)"), doing so for all succeeding films in the franchise.

Columbus declined to direct _[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of
Azkaban](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban_\(film\) "Harry Potter
and the Prisoner of Azkaban \(film\)")_ , only acting as producer. Mexican
director [Alfonso Cuarón](/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n "Alfonso Cuarón") took
over the job, and after shooting in 2003, the film was released on 4 June
2004. Due to the fourth film beginning its production before the third's
release, [Mike Newell](/wiki/Mike_Newell_\(director\) "Mike Newell
\(director\)") was chosen as the director for _[Harry Potter and the Goblet of
Fire](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_\(film\) "Harry Potter and the
Goblet of Fire \(film\)")_ , released on 18 November 2005.[179] Newell became
the first British director of the series, with television director [David
Yates](/wiki/David_Yates "David Yates") following suit after he was chosen to
helm _[Harry Potter and the Order of the
Phoenix](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix_\(film\) "Harry
Potter and the Order of the Phoenix \(film\)")_. Production began in January
2006 and the film was released the following year in July 2007.[180] After
executives were "really delighted" with his work on the film, Yates was
selected to direct _[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood
Prince](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince_\(film\) "Harry Potter
and the Half-Blood Prince \(film\)")_ , which was released on 15 July
2009.[181][182][183][184]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Hogwarts_model_studio_tour.jpg/220px-
Hogwarts_model_studio_tour.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hogwarts_model_studio_tour.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hogwarts_model_studio_tour.jpg "Enlarge")

A studio model of [Hogwarts](/wiki/Hogwarts "Hogwarts") Castle as it appears
in the films.

In March 2008, Warner Bros. President and COO [Alan F.
Horn](/wiki/Alan_F._Horn "Alan F. Horn") announced that the final instalment
in the series, _[Harry Potter and the Deathly
Hallows](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows "Harry Potter and the
Deathly Hallows")_ , would be released in two cinematic parts: _[Part
1](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_1 "Harry Potter
and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1")_ on 19 November 2010 and _[Part
2](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "Harry Potter
and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2")_ on 15 July 2011. [Production of both
parts](/wiki/Production_of_Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows "Production of
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows") started in February 2009, with the
final day of principal photography taking place on 12 June 2010.[185][186]

Rowling had creative control on the film series, observing the filmmaking
process of _Philosopher 's Stone_ and serving as producer on the two-part
_Deathly Hallows_ , alongside [David Heyman](/wiki/David_Heyman "David
Heyman") and [David Barron](/wiki/David_Barron_\(film_producer\) "David Barron
\(film producer\)").[187] The _Harry Potter_ films have been top-rank box
office hits, with all eight releases on the [list of highest-grossing films
worldwide](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of highest-grossing
films"). _Philosopher 's Stone_ was the highest-grossing _Harry Potter_ film
up until the release of the final instalment of the series, _Deathly Hallows_
, while _Prisoner of Azkaban_ grossed the least.[188] As well as being a
financial success, the film series has also been a success among film
critics.[189][190]

Opinions of the films are generally divided among fans, with one group
preferring the more faithful approach of the first two films, and another
group preferring the more stylised character-driven approach of the later
films.[191] Rowling has been constantly supportive of all the films and
evaluated _Deathly Hallows_ as her "favourite one" in the
series.[192][193][194][195] She wrote on her website of the changes in the
book-to-film transition, "It is simply impossible to incorporate every one of
my storylines into a film that has to be kept under four hours long. Obviously
films have restrictions novels do not have, constraints of time and budget; I
can create dazzling effects relying on nothing but the interaction of my own
and my readers' imaginations".[196]

At the [64th British Academy Film
Awards](/wiki/64th_British_Academy_Film_Awards "64th British Academy Film
Awards") in February 2011, Rowling was joined by producers David Heyman and
David Barron along with directors David Yates, Alfonso Cuarón and Mike Newell
in collecting the [Michael Balcon Award for Outstanding British Contribution
to
Cinema](/wiki/64th_British_Academy_Film_Awards#Michael_Balcon_Award_for_Outstanding_British_Contribution_to_Cinema
"64th British Academy Film Awards") on behalf of all the films in the series.
Actors [Rupert Grint](/wiki/Rupert_Grint "Rupert Grint") and [Emma
Watson](/wiki/Emma_Watson "Emma Watson"), who play main characters [Ron
Weasley](/wiki/Ron_Weasley "Ron Weasley") and [Hermione
Granger](/wiki/Hermione_Granger "Hermione Granger"), were also in
attendance.[197][198]

#### Spin-off prequels

A new series consisting of five films, beginning with _[Fantastic Beasts and
Where to Find Them](/wiki/Fantastic_Beasts_and_Where_to_Find_Them_\(film\)
"Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them \(film\)")_ , will take place before
the main series.[199] The first film was released on 18 November 2016 and the
next two are due to be released in 2018 and 2020.[200] Rowling wrote the
screenplay for the first instalment, marking her first foray into
screenwriting.

### Games

Main article: [Harry Potter video games](/wiki/Harry_Potter_video_games "Harry
Potter video games")

A number of other non-interactive media games and board games have been
released such as _[Cluedo](/wiki/Cluedo "Cluedo") Harry Potter Edition_,
_[Scene It?](/wiki/Scene_It%3F "Scene It?") Harry Potter_ and _[Lego Harry
Potter](/wiki/Lego_Harry_Potter "Lego Harry Potter")_ models, which are
influenced by the themes of both the novels and films.

There are thirteen _Harry Potter_ video games, eight corresponding with the
films and books and five spin-offs. The film/book-based games are produced by
[Electronic Arts](/wiki/Electronic_Arts "Electronic Arts"), as was _[Harry
Potter: Quidditch World Cup](/wiki/Harry_Potter:_Quidditch_World_Cup "Harry
Potter: Quidditch World Cup")_ , with the game version of the first entry in
the series, _[Philosopher's
Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone_\(video_game\) "Harry
Potter and the Philosopher's Stone \(video game\)")_, being released in
November 2001. _Harry Potter and the Philosopher 's Stone_ went on to become
one of the best-selling [PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation "PlayStation") games
ever.[201] The video games were released to coincide with the films,
containing scenery and details from the films as well as the tone and spirit
of the books. Objectives usually occur in and around [Hogwarts](/wiki/Hogwarts
"Hogwarts"), along with various other magical areas. The story and design of
the games follow the selected film's characterisation and plot; EA worked
closely with Warner Bros. to include scenes from the films. The last game in
the series, _Deathly Hallows_ , was split, with _[Part
1](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_1_\(video_game\)
"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1 \(video game\)")_ released in
November 2010 and _[Part
2](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_2_\(video_game\)
"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2 \(video game\)")_ debuting on
consoles in July 2011. The two-part game forms the first entry to convey an
intense theme of action and violence, with the gameplay revolving around a
third-person shooter style format.[202][203]

The spin-off games _[Lego Harry Potter: Years
1–4](/wiki/Lego_Harry_Potter:_Years_1%E2%80%934 "Lego Harry Potter: Years
1–4")_ and _[Lego Harry Potter: Years
5–7](/wiki/Lego_Harry_Potter:_Years_5%E2%80%937 "Lego Harry Potter: Years
5–7")_ were developed by [Traveller's Tales](/wiki/Traveller%27s_Tales
"Traveller's Tales") and published by [Warner Bros. Interactive
Entertainment](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Interactive_Entertainment "Warner Bros.
Interactive Entertainment"). The spin-off games _[Book of
Spells](/wiki/Book_of_Spells "Book of Spells")_ and _[Book of
Potions](/wiki/Book_of_Potions "Book of Potions")_ were developed by [SCE
London Studio](/wiki/SCE_London_Studio "SCE London Studio") and use the
[Wonderbook](/wiki/Wonderbook "Wonderbook"), an [augmented
reality](/wiki/Augmented_reality "Augmented reality") book designed to be used
in conjunction with the [PlayStation Move](/wiki/PlayStation_Move "PlayStation
Move") and [PlayStation Eye](/wiki/PlayStation_Eye "PlayStation Eye").[204]
The _Harry Potter_ universe is also featured in _[Lego
Dimensions](/wiki/Lego_Dimensions "Lego Dimensions")_ , with the settings and
side characters featured in the Harry Potter Adventure World, and Harry,
Voldemort, and Hermione as playable characters. In 2017, [Warner Bros.
Interactive Entertainment](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Interactive_Entertainment
"Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment") opened its own Harry Potter themed
game design studio, by the name of [Portkey Games](/wiki/Portkey_Games
"Portkey Games"); before releasing [Hogwarts
Mystery](/wiki/Harry_Potter:_Hogwarts_Mystery "Harry Potter: Hogwarts
Mystery") in 2018, developed by [Jam City](/wiki/Jam_City "Jam City").[205]

### Audiobooks

All seven _Harry Potter_ books have been released in unabridged audiobook
versions, with [Stephen Fry](/wiki/Stephen_Fry "Stephen Fry") reading the UK
editions and [Jim Dale](/wiki/Jim_Dale "Jim Dale") voicing the series for the
American editions.[206][207]

### Stage production

Main article: [Harry Potter and the Cursed
Child](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child "Harry Potter and the Cursed
Child")

_Harry Potter and the Cursed Child: Parts I and II_ is a play which serves as
a sequel to the books, beginning nineteen years after the events of _[Harry
Potter and the Deathly Hallows](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows
"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows")_. It was written by [Jack
Thorne](/wiki/Jack_Thorne_\(writer\) "Jack Thorne \(writer\)") based on an
original new story by Thorne, Rowling and [John Tiffany](/wiki/John_Tiffany
"John Tiffany").[208] It has run at the [Palace
Theatre](/wiki/Palace_Theatre,_London "Palace Theatre, London") in London's
[West End](/wiki/West_End_of_London "West End of London") since previews began
on 7 June 2016 with an official premiere on 30 June 2016.[209] The first four
months of tickets for the June–September performances were sold out within
several hours upon release.[210] Forthcoming productions are planned for
Broadway[211] and Melbourne.[212]

The script was released as a book at the time of the premiere, with a revised
version following the next year.

## Attractions

### The Wizarding World of Harry Potter

Main article: [The Wizarding World of Harry
Potter](/wiki/The_Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter "The Wizarding World of
Harry Potter")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_Castle.jpg/220px-
Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_Castle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_Castle.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wizarding_World_of_Harry_Potter_Castle.jpg "Enlarge")

Hogwarts Castle as depicted in the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, located in
Universal Orlando Resort's Island of Adventure

After the success of the films and books, Universal and Warner Brothers
announced they would create _The Wizarding World of Harry Potter_ , a new
_Harry Potter_ -themed expansion to the [Islands of
Adventure](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure "Islands of Adventure") theme park at
[Universal Orlando Resort](/wiki/Universal_Orlando_Resort "Universal Orlando
Resort") in Florida. The land officially opened to the public on 18 June
2010.[213] It includes a re-creation of [Hogsmeade](/wiki/Hogsmeade
"Hogsmeade") and several rides. The flagship attraction is _[Harry Potter and
the Forbidden Journey](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Forbidden_Journey "Harry
Potter and the Forbidden Journey")_ , which exists within a re-creation of
[Hogwarts](/wiki/Hogwarts "Hogwarts") School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Other
rides include _[Dragon Challenge](/wiki/Dragon_Challenge "Dragon Challenge")_
, a pair of [inverted roller coasters](/wiki/Inverted_roller_coasters
"Inverted roller coasters"), and _[Flight of the
Hippogriff](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Hippogriff "Flight of the Hippogriff")_ , a
[family roller coaster](/wiki/Family_roller_coaster "Family roller coaster").

Four years later, on 8 July 2014, Universal opened a _Harry Potter_ -themed
area at the [Universal Studios Florida](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Florida
"Universal Studios Florida") theme park. It includes a re-creation of [Diagon
Alley](/wiki/Diagon_Alley "Diagon Alley") and connecting alleys and a small
section of [Muggle](/wiki/Muggle "Muggle") [London](/wiki/London "London").
The flagship attraction is _[Harry Potter and the Escape from
Gringotts](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Escape_from_Gringotts "Harry Potter and
the Escape from Gringotts")_ roller coaster ride. Universal also added a
completely functioning recreation of the [Hogwarts
Express](/wiki/Hogwarts_Express "Hogwarts Express") connecting Kings Cross
Station at Universal Studios Florida to the Hogsmeade station at Islands of
Adventure. Both Hogsmeade and Diagon Alley contain many shops and restaurants
from the book series, including Weasley's Wizard Wheezes and The Leaky
Cauldron.

On 15 July 2014, _The Wizarding World of Harry Potter_ opened at the
[Universal Studios Japan](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Japan "Universal Studios
Japan") theme park in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka "Osaka"), Japan. It includes the
village of Hogsmeade, _Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey_ ride, and
_Flight of the Hippogriff_ roller coaster.[214][215]

On 7 April 2016, _The Wizarding World of Harry Potter_ opened at the
[Universal Studios Hollywood](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Hollywood "Universal
Studios Hollywood") theme park near [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los
Angeles"), [California](/wiki/California "California").[216][217]

### The Making of Harry Potter

Main article: [Warner Bros. Studio Tour London - The Making of Harry
Potter](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studio_Tour_London_-_The_Making_of_Harry_Potter
"Warner Bros. Studio Tour London - The Making of Harry Potter")

In March 2011, Warner Bros. announced plans to build a tourist attraction in
the United Kingdom to showcase the _Harry Potter_ film series. _The Making of
Harry Potter_ is a behind-the-scenes walking tour featuring authentic sets,
costumes and props from the film series. The attraction is located at [Warner
Bros. Studios, Leavesden](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studios,_Leavesden "Warner Bros.
Studios, Leavesden"), where all eight of the _Harry Potter_ films were made.
Warner Bros. constructed two new sound stages to house and showcase the famous
sets from each of the British-made productions, following a £100 million
investment.[218] It opened to the public in March 2012.[219]
